0.text:
Some of you will have seen University Wipeout
sweep across Facebook in the last 2 weeks

4.text:
or so. It involves setting up inflatable obstacle
courses around the UK, and is based on the

9.text:
former TV show Total Wipeout fronted by Richard
Hammond, which is most likely to be the job

14.text:
Hammond is currently hoping for to salvage
his career.

17.text:
This idea has received a huge response on
social media. But despite this, the organisers

22.text:
have managed to completely screw it up. For
reasons about to be explained it's advised

26.text:
that you don’t promote anything to do with
this page or give them any of the personal

30.text:
data they ask for. It’s a shame because
University Wipeout is a brilliant idea, but

34.text:
the person behind these events has demonstrated
worse judgment than whoever thought Kim Kardashian

39.text:
children’s clothing should be a thing.
Later, I’ll also be talking about an idea

46.text:
to try and rescue this mess and save the concept.
But first, I'm obliged to show my working

51.text:
and explain why I find this stuff so irritating.
So let's take the journey folks. You're already

55.text:
procrastinating from exam revision anyway,
what the harm’s in a little longer?

59.text:
So let's take a look. Well, we can’t fault
them on their social media skills. There are

63.text:
more than 50 of these events with thousands
and thousands of attendees, many of my friends

68.text:
have already signed up.
Basically, Wipeout comes to your university,

71.text:
you get a chance to go on the course, and
there’s also cash prizes involved. Amazing!

75.text:
Where do I sign? Okay. So that link takes
me to a Google Form. Which is basically the

79.text:
data collection equivalent of Poundland. I’d
expect that for some small time project but

83.text:
not really a national event for thousands
of people.

86.text:
So maybe we should take a look at their website
to get a bit of background. What? They don’t

91.text:
have a website? Or a Twitter? You’re organising
more than 50 student events across the UK,

97.text:
and you didn’t bother to set up Twitter
[Sigh] Jesus.

101.text:
There’s also confusion as to whether you’re
doing events at every uni you’ve said, or

106.text:
just one in Cardiff, and coaching people down
from other universities to compete. What the

111.text:
fuck is this, 50:50? What is your plan? People
are asking but you’ve published zero information

116.text:
anywhere. For fuck’s sake this thing is
such a mystery I’m starting to think it

119.text:
was planned by Steven Moffat.
But I’m sure that this lack of information

123.text:
won’t backfire on you at all, University
Wipeout. I’m 100% certain your audience

127.text:
will believe everything is valid and no one
will say this is a. Oh no. Ohhhh dear. Ohhhh

147.text:
dear.
So you get the point, the response has been

159.text:
insanely polarised, some people love it, and
some have actually gone to the trouble of

163.text:
commenting on every single event to warn against
signing up, claiming that this is all an elaborate

168.text:
attempt to get your personal details.
So is it real or a scam? Well… It’s hard

173.text:
to tell. Because after that the trail goes
cold. There’s just no way to find out who

176.text:
actually created this.
Unless the Google Form is watermarked with

180.text:
the name of the organisation it came from.
Oh look it is. Where we find this name…

185.text:
Electric Ents. What? Well anyway if we look
up these people we see they’re a pretty

190.text:
standard student events company based in Cardiff.
A little more digging, and we can see that

194.text:
the Co-founder of Electric Ents is Christian
James, who also uses the name Christian Samuel.

199.text:
He’s currently in the press defending another
venture, The Outdoor Cinema, responding to

202.text:
claims that this is a data collection scam.
Oh dear.

205.text:
But I want to be fair on this guy, the article
says these are the opinions of bloggers. And

210.text:
bloggers aren’t any kind of objective source
of information, unless you’re 13. I suppose

221.text:
the word of a university however, does weigh
more heavily, so it’s interesting to see

225.text:
that 3 universities seem to have no idea what
wipeout is. Hmm you’d think if you were

231.text:
going to promote events using the university’s
names then you might at least give them a

235.text:
call. Probably far too much work though.
You know, all this reminds me of something

239.text:
I saw a few of weeks ago. There were all these
Facebook events called ‘Bring Radio 1’s

243.text:
Big Weekend To Your City’. People joined
these in droves, hoping to bring Big Weekend

248.text:
to where they live. These follow the same
pattern as Wipeout: events targeted at a list

251.text:
of different places, several thousand people
attending, and promotion of a sign-up link.

256.text:
Curious, isn’t it? Then the BBC said that
it was all a scam and they disappeared. What

261.text:
I’m showing you are basically snapshots
that google has saved.

264.text:
But because both these Facebook Pages were
set up completely anonymously, there’s nothing

268.text:
to suggest the same people behind University
Wipeout also created the Radio 1 Big Weekend

273.text:
‘Scam’. Unless...
Now bear with me here cos there’s some technical

277.text:
wankery. But let’s have a look at this shortened
link which has funnelled everyone from the

280.text:
Facebook events to the Wipeout sign-up Form.
What a lot of people don’t know about bitly

284.text:
links, is that simply by adding a plus at
the end, you can access information about

288.text:
it. Including how many people clicked on it
and who created it. The Wipeout sign-up link

292.text:
was created by this registered bitly account,
christianunicribs.

296.text:
And what do we find? The same user that created
the Wipeout link also created the link used

301.text:
on the fake Big Weekend pages. This one sent
nearly 8000 Facebook users to another google

306.text:
form alleging to be a petition for the cause.
This has now been taken down. We can see that

311.text:
after the 7th April, once Radio 1 came out
and said the Big Weekend Pages were scams,

316.text:
the activity dies to almost nothing.
On this bitly profile there’s also this

320.text:
link to a petition for No More Tuition Fees.
Which is an innocent-looking campaign page

324.text:
which started posting this month. It’s created
a protest event for later this year with a

329.text:
supposed 4000 people attending, and it’s
attracted a lot of activists who have used

333.text:
it to share information on the movement. And
we also find links to another Google Form

338.text:
which again has mysteriously disappeared.
For starters, any normal campaign would use

342.text:
a petition website like Change.org or 38 Degrees.
But what’s more shocking about this page

347.text:
is what they’ve chosen to post for their
followers. They could share articles from

351.text:
the media, maybe information about how people
can support the cause. But no, what they decide

355.text:
to post instead - one of the only things on
there at all - is a list of Freshers Facebook

360.text:
groups all managed by Christian James. And
oh look, a post promoting University Wipeout.

366.text:
Jesus Christ mate I have to hand it to you,
you have balls because that is bold. Performing

371.text:
a barefaced bait & switch on students, masquerading
as a cause that people care about to promote

377.text:
yourself for personal gain. Remember what
happened to the last guy who told students

381.text:
he was against tuition fees but turned out
to be lying? You should switch to selling

384.text:
tickets for a cinema night where the only
thing played is that kiss between Madonna

388.text:
& Drake over and over on a loop for 3 hours,
even that would be less of a shit sandwich

393.text:
than what you’re doing now.
From a scam page shut down by Radio 1, to

397.text:
The Open Air Cinema, to No More Tuition Fees,
to a housing website University Cribs, to

402.text:
University Wipeout, even something called
‘I’m going to University in 2015’ - Come

407.text:
on Electric Ents you’re just trying too
hard now - This reveals a wide attempt to

410.text:
collect data from and in some cases mislead
thousands upon thousands of students across

415.text:
the UK. Now we can’t prove that this bitly
account belongs to Christian James, I’ve

420.text:
asked him through his personal Facebook profile,
but he hasn’t responded.

423.text:
But here’s another thing that gives us some
interesting insight. This post from a venue

427.text:
in Bath back in January. They apologise for
sharing a link to another different Big Weekend

432.text:
Facebook page (which again uses links created
by the christianunicribs account). They removed

437.text:
the link because it was “not a proper bid,
but an attempt by local club promoters to

442.text:
publicise another event in the future.”
To which a Mr Christian James had this to

446.text:
reply with
So, if this University Wipeout is the same

457.text:
scheme by the same people behind Big Weekend,
we can guess that they’ll “publicise another

461.text:
event in future”. And surprise surprise
we see this photo telling us to invite 25

466.text:
friends to this, a Freshers’ Paint Party.
So, was this all just an extremely elaborate,

472.text:
cynical strategy to get students to sign up
for a UV club night?

476.text:
Maybe. But it’s a lot of effort to go to.
Maybe they will actually do more Wipeout events

480.text:
than just in Cardiff.
But the point is this. These guys have now

484.text:
likely taken thousands of records of personal
data from the likes of you and me, and seem

489.text:
pretty comfortable with blatantly deceiving
people. Not to mention that data protection

493.text:
laws are pretty clear: when collecting someone’s
data you must disclose who you are and exactly

498.text:
what you’re doing with that information,
University Wipeout hasn’t done either. And

502.text:
Electric Ents is also missing from the ICO
register, the register that every company

506.text:
that collects data has to be signed up to
by law.

509.text:
Anyway, some of you will likely be saying
by now that I'm just a massive killjoy.

513.text:
But I want to make it clear that I don’t
have anything against club promoters, I’ve

517.text:
actually worked on marketing projects in the
past that involved signing up students to

521.text:
a database. But that’s why this pisses me
off so much. When a small minority deceive

525.text:
and manipulate individuals to get them to
sign up for something, then people start to

529.text:
distrust everything they see online. The effect
is like a fine crop spray of shit everywhere

534.text:
which poisons all club promoters and companies
who work in an honest, transparent and fair

539.text:
way. But anyway let me tell you where I’m
going with this.

542.text:
Honestly, this is a great idea which should
happen, and we have a huge amount of enthusiasm

546.text:
behind these events. And it’s completely
possible, there are several events companies

550.text:
that let you hire out Wipeout courses, and
Essex Uni even did this a few years ago.

554.text:
It’s just that these particular organisers
have executed them so badly that they’ve

558.text:
lost a lot of people’s trust. So, I’m
going to show Electric Christian James Ents

562.text:
how you’re supposed to organise a cause.
With this petition to Cardiff University.

567.text:
If you want to help salvage this idea, and
want to help a children’s charity at the

571.text:
same time, then this is for you. Let’s block
their so-called National Event taking place

575.text:
in Cardiff, and make our own happen. And instead
of spamming adverts for UV club nights, this

580.text:
event will be in support of The Children’s
Trust.

583.text:
Why The Children’s Trust? Well Richard Hammond
became the public face of this charity after

587.text:
his accident on Top Gear, as they specialise
in helping children with brain injuries.

590.text:
Let’s take this brilliant idea out of the
hands of the spammers, and use it for good.

595.text:
You can sign the petition even if you don’t
go to Cardiff. But also, if you’re not Cardiff

598.text:
University you can get involved through your
University RAG group or Student Union. Try

603.text:
to replace your local Wipeout event with The
Childrens Trust Wipeout instead.

607.text:
So how do we get this cause seen by as wide
an audience as possible? Let’s try a technique

612.text:
I learnt from another page. Hijack a cause
to promote our own shit! Post and comment

616.text:
with the petition link all over University
Wipeout. Let’s aim for full visibility.

621.text:
Every single post, every event, let’s ram
this down their every digital orifice to make

625.text:
people fully aware that there’s an alternative.
And whilst I’m already ripping off John

629.text:
Oliver, why don’t we start a hashtag as
well. Go to your twitter now and tweet using

633.text:
#ChildrensTrustWipeout. Come on. It’s not
like you’re doing anything important. Tweet

637.text:
The Children’s Trust, tweet Total Wipeout,
tweet Richard Hammond. Tweet everyone.

641.text:
And finally, if you have given your personal
details to any page connected to Electric

645.text:
Ents and you believe they’ve breached your
data protection rights, the Information Commissioner’s

649.text:
Office is who you should report this to. You
can tweet them @ICOnews with your complaint.

654.text:
Whatever you say is completely your decision,
but for me, I think this image sums it up

659.text:
best. Thanks for watching and please sign
the petition and share it with your friends.
